thread.title: Quantico edges out The Beautiful Lie
thread.title_full: Quantico edges out The Beautiful Lie

author: David Dale
title: Quantico edges out The Beautiful Lie
text:
The Beautiful Lie drew 540,000 viewers for its first episode. 
The battle between Australia's most radiant actress and the world's most gorgeous woman was narrowly lost last Sunday by the little Aussie battler, proving that drama is not dead on mainstream television but that we seem to prefer slick American action thrillers to our own more thoughtful tales.
Strictly speaking, the ABC's The Beautiful Lie is a Russian tale – based on Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina but transposed to Melbourne 140 years later. It stars Sarah Snook (the aforementioned radiant one) as Anna (now a tennis pro instead of an aristocrat). Last Sunday, Snook went up against Priyanka Chopra​, a former Miss World who plays FBI trainee Alex Parrish in Channel Seven's Quantico​ .
Quantico drew an audience of 625,000 in Australia's mainland capitals and The Beautiful Lie drew 540,000. Between them they just about wiped out Channel Ten's Limitless , which managed a mere 455,000, putting a tiny dent in Ten's delight in its success with The Bachelorette , which keeps scoring above 900,000.
The Verdict launched with 520,000 viewers but dropped to 357,000 in its second week. Photo: Seven 
As well as rolling out a squadron of new shows right now, the networks are being ruthless in disposing of any that don't quickly measure up. Seven axed a hypnotism show called Mesmerised after only one week because it drew 411,000. What does this imply about the fate of The Verdict , Karl Stefanovic's noisy homage to Q&A ? It launched with 520,000 and dropped to 357,000 in its second week (while its ABC inspiration pulled the usual 596,000). Stefanovic is a buddy of Nine boss David Gyngell, so he may last a little longer than Seven's hypnotist.
Advertisement OzTAM estimates these were the most watched shows in the week ending October 19:
#1 The Block (Nine), 1.14 million
#2 800 Words (Seven), 1.05m
#3 Nine News Sunday (Nine), 1.05m
#4 Seven News Sunday (Seven), 1.05m
#5 The X Factor (Seven),1.02m
